question: Question_Section_001_10_(b)
statement:
There are $9$ courses I want to take next term. All $9$ courses are
offered during the same $5$ time slots. How many ways do I have to fill
those $5$ time slots?

\emph{For this question, a numerical answer is required as a final
answer.}
sols:
When selecting courses, the order does not matter. So I am really
interested in a combination here. I have want to select $5$ of the $9$
available courses, so I am looking at $\binom{9}{5}$.

\begin{align*}
\binom{9}{5} &= \frac{9!}{5! (9-5)!}\\
&= \frac{9!}{5!}\cdot \frac{1}{4!}\\
&= \frac{9\cdot8\cdot7\cdot 6}{4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1}\\
&= 9\cdot2\cdot7 \\
&=126\end{align*}

There are $126$ ways to fill the 5 timeslots.
hints:
In contrast to
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_Section_001_10_(a)}{part
(a)}, the order in which one chooses his courses does not matter. So
this is just a combinations question.
